A good flexible job.
cons: You are on your own if you work at night, it's chaos and short staffing every time. You may be able to use the restroom once or if lucky twice in twelve hours and it's only ever so often you get your lunch break. Your replacement with not show up on time and you cannot leave until they get there. Could be another hour or two.

review_title: Choose a different health system to work for
pros: On the hospital side, very nice people. Especially in ED, where they have been bombarded by COVID for 2 years now. Some of the most caring people you will ever meet.
cons: Pay is appallingly low across the system and across job titles. MAs were given a pay increase this year, but it still does not reflect market value when Mercy and Integris pay more. On the clinic side, there is very poor management. Providers and management constantly clash, which is nothing new in healthcare. But since they cannot reach solutions together, they often place blame on lower staff.

pros: Mangers are not consistent and concerns are not taken serious. Great benefits.
cons: Poor management not taken serious, poor scheduling

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Norman Regional emphasizes their work culture heavily on day 1, and I was honestly surprised at how true it turned out to be. It's one thing to be told that a company has a good culture, and another thing entirely to see it. 

The hospital operates on an acronym ICARE, which stands for Integrity, Communication, Attitude, Results, and Engagement. 

Most of these are self-explanatory, but the point is that they care about each "healer" having a positive attitude, strong values, good communication skills with patients and co-workers, etc.

They call each person on payroll a "healer" instead of employee, because they want everyone to understand that each role is crucial for the overall success of the hospital. In order for the doctors and nurses to be successful, each department in the hospital from accounting to food services needs to do their best. 

It's been an adjustment for me, because I came from a place that was entirely opposite. I was surrounded by negative people, micromanagement, and management who didn't care about their employees well being.

It helps that Norman Regional is a private company that doesn't need to focus on stockholders or profits specifically. I believe that makes all the difference.
cons: Pay could be higher for certain positions

review_title: Norman Regional struggles to maintain it's smallexistence in this medical ecomony without financial or physician support
pros: The strongest asset NRHS has is it's staff and the cohesion of the community they create. It is not a huge conglomerate system so that each employee is still a bit more than a number on the payroll. When approval is needed to put a new idea into play, it isn't months before it can be presented to corporate in another state who know nothing of the local needs.
cons: Top heavy in upper management, yet budget shortfalls are expected to be met by triming the lowest paid hourly workers, of which there are already too few, and doubling responsibilities of those left who are already stretched far too thin. Within the last few months, all but two unit managers have turned over, and those responsibilites are being left dangling or shoved to the remaining survivors who are unable to maintain control of all their responsibilities.

review_title: If only it were about the patients...

pros: If you want to be busy, this is the perfect place for you.

Most coworkers are great but eventually are too stressed to be content in their job.  Promise monetary changes as well as structural changes none have happened.

pros: Fast paced so day flies by, meet many employees who become friends, work very challenging, and you know you are appreciated by the staff for what you do to help them out. Lots of work to do so feel you are needed very much and can count on you to get things done with accuracy.
cons: Different departments within the hospital vary depending on what manager you get so they... hospital departments are not run entirely t same. Its up to the manager/supervisor regarding how strick and pressure-filled the job, is depending how much workload you are given. Many times you will be walking at at5 pa,earound the hospital ,as well as working at ur desk for long periods of time also. Very stressful. Also BEWARE that employees who will retire soon tend to get pushed out of theirs jobs BEFORE they can,get there retirement.  Not good at all!!!  Doesnt matter how long you have worked there. Seen it happen to multiple employees right before there retirement !
